qas.question: Before what year was Cubism considered the most innovative?
With the assistance of what dealer did Cubism return as  a central consideration for artists after World War I?
In what year did Rosenberg exhibit Cubist works at  Galerie de l’Effort Moderne?
In which city did Galerie de l’Effort Moderne take place?
Before what year was Cubism considered the least innovative?
With the assistance of what dealer did Cubism return as a central consideration for artists after World War II?
In what year did Rosenberg refuse to exhibit Cubist works at Galerie de l’Effort Moderne?
In which city was Galerie de l’Effort Moderne banned from?

context: The most innovative period of Cubism was before <a0_0><b4_0>1914<b4_0/><a0_0/>. After World War I, with the support given by the dealer <a1_0>Léonce Rosenberg<a1_0/>, Cubism returned as a central issue for artists, and continued as such until the mid-1920s when its avant-garde status was rendered questionable by the emergence of geometric abstraction and Surrealism in Paris. Many Cubists, including Picasso, Braque, Gris, Léger, Gleizes, and Metzinger, while developing other styles, returned periodically to Cubism, even well after 1925. Cubism reemerged during the 1920s and the 1930s in the work of the American Stuart Davis and the Englishman Ben Nicholson. In France, however, <b6_0>Cubism<b6_0/> experienced a decline beginning in about 1925. <b5_0>Léonce Rosenberg<b5_0/> exhibited not only the artists stranded by Kahnweiler’s exile but others including Laurens, Lipchitz, Metzinger, Gleizes, Csaky, Herbin and Severini. In <a2_0><b7_0>1918<b7_0/><a2_0/> Rosenberg presented a series of Cubist exhibitions at his Galerie de l’Effort Moderne in <a3_0><b8_0>Paris<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Attempts were made by Louis Vauxcelles to claim that Cubism was dead, but these exhibitions, along with a well-organized Cubist show at the 1920 Salon des Indépendants and a revival of the Salon de la Section d’Or in the same year, demonstrated it was still alive.
